items.name: Hand Contours
items.synopsis: As a way to avoid drawing from memory. My drawing and painting class made numerous blind, continuous, and modified hand contour drawings.
items.description: These assignemnts were a chance for me to practice my still life skills, something I haven't had much experience in doing. The biggest challenge was learning to pace myself properly and also to avoid doing hairy lines.

items.name: First hand
items.description: My first blind contour drawing. I ended up spending too much time on the thumb and then rushing the rest of the hand.

items.name: Interior Lines
items.description: For the second blind contour sketch I was told to focus more on doing interior lines. We were also given more time which let me pace myself better.

items.name: Fist
items.description: Another blind contour. This time I changed my pose to give myself more of a challenge.

items.name: 2nd Hand
items.description: Another 3 minute blind contour. I once again spent too much time on the thumb an then rushed the rest of the hand.

items.name: Continuous
items.description: After doing blind contour, the class moved onto doing continuous line countour. As I could look at the paper, I was able to join the entire hand together as once cohesive piece.

items.name: Continuous 2
items.description: Another continuous drawing. I switched up the pose again because I wanted to practice getting the bends in the fingers right.

items.name: Modified
items.description: Modified contour drawing. Im especially proud of the wrinkles around the thumb.

items.name: Polygon Mesh
items.description: The last hand drawing we did was cross-contour. As I wanted to practice my modelling skills, I decided to make mine as if it was a wireframe render.

items.name: Contour Still Life
items.synopsis: As part of an assingment in my drawing & painting class, I decided to make a still life in the style of a 3d wireframe render.
items.description: Although the topology is terrible, It was an interesting challenge trying to imply the curve in the objects.

items.name: Still Life
items.description: The complete still life. There are a few perspective issues in certain areas, but I'm very happy with how the piece looks.

items.name: Reference
items.description: The reference image. We weren't able to observe the objects as multiple classes needed to use them, however I did spend time analysing their form when doing the topology lines.

items.name: Value Head
items.synopsis: As part of our value unit in drawing & painting, the class had to do value drawings of the head.
items.description: I had never done a proper portrait drawing before so this was a new experience for me. I especially enjoyed the blending technique as It was the easiest for me to add and subtract value.

items.name: Head
items.description: The final animation. I wasn't able to render it in high quality as it required an insanely high sample count.

items.name: Reference
items.description: The reference image. Taking this took much longer than it should have.

items.name: Progress photo
items.description: A photo of me working on my face. I decided to do hair last as I knew it would be the most difficult to shade.

items.name: Light Study
items.synopsis: A lighting study I did in the style of rembrant. I wanted to experimenting with painting light on black instead of the traditional technique of painting on white.
items.description: The piece only took an hour, I was bored one evening and felt like doing a painting so I grabbed a canvas and some paints and started playing around.

items.name: Study
items.description: The full composition. Halfway through painting I decided to paint a hole in the center of the pot, but I feel that I didn't paint enough light for it to be noticable.

items.name: AP Sketchbook
items.synopsis: AS part of my AP 2D Art & Design submission, I had to create sketchbook pieces that show my train of thought.

items.name: Final Animation
items.description: The final animation. I wasn't able to render it in high quality as it required an insanely high sample count.

items.name: Sketchbook Pieces
items.synopsis: A collection of my sketchbook pieces.
items.description: As I usually create my digital art straight from my head, I have very few pieces in my sketchbooks. However these were the best ones that I could find.

items.name: Final Animation
items.description: The final animation. I wasn't able to render it in high quality as it required an insanely high sample count.

items.name: Coloring Concepts
items.synopsis: For my drawing & painting class, we were told to create a piece from our imagination and draw it using color.
items.description: I chose to make...

items.name: Final Piece
items.description: The final piece.

items.name: Figure drawing
items.synopsis: A couple figure drawings that I did during my free time.
items.description: I generally avoid drawing characters as it a domain that I enjoy doing. However I felt I needed to do a few before heading off to university.

items.name: Final Animation
items.description: The final animation. I wasn't able to render it in high quality as it required an insanely high sample count.

items.name: City Racing
items.synopsis: I had always wanted to do a high energy car chase animation. So one day I sat down and did it!
items.description: Lol

items.name: Final Animation
items.description: The final animation. I wasn't able to render it in high quality as it required an insanely high sample count.

items.name: Concept
items.description: The first concept. I ended changing things because I wasn't getting the up close action packed feeling.

items.name: Layout
items.description: The scene layout. I remember basing it off a street in tokyo.

items.name: Viewport
items.description: I was very proud of the motion of the car. The sharp swing and the levelling out, all while the wheels kept spinning was very satisfying.

items.name: Creature Breach
items.synopsis: After spending a couple weeks messing around in Houdini. I decided I wanted to attempt a large scale fluid simulation. I had seen a similar creature breach animation online and felt like learning how to do that myself.
items.description: Lol

items.name: Fluid
items.description: The fluid simulation. It took about 72 hours non-stop to bake.

items.name: Base
items.description: The base animation. This was definitely the easiest part of the entire project.

items.name: Saliva
items.description: I also made a saliva simulation for the shot, but I ended up not using it for anything.

items.name: Desert Temple
items.synopsis: After hearing about the full Unreal Engine 5 release, I decided to play around with Megascans and Lumen. I was playing Tomb Raider at the time and wanted to making something that resembled a desert temple.
items.description: Lol
items.tools: Unreal Engine 5, Quixel Megascans, DaVinci Resolve

items.name: Full Animation
items.description: The full animation. The hardest part was getting the animation to work without breaking the scene.

items.name: Light
items.description: A quick lighting test. The fact that this software is free amazes me.

items.name: Wide
items.description: A large shot of the scene. I was able to throw this together in about an hour.

items.name: Ornithopter
items.synopsis: After watching Dune, I loved the animations for the ornithopters and I had to try it for myself.
items.description: Lol
items.tools: Blender, Quixel Megascans, After Effects, DaVinci Resolve

items.name: Full Animation
items.description: The full animation. This was done all over a single weekend.

items.name: Hack
items.description: The ornithopter itself was a basic projection mapping hack.

items.name: Wide
items.description: The hardest part of the animation was getting the wings to flutter properly. I also wanted to have the sand react to the ornithopter, but that was too difficult.

items.name: Spiderman Swing
items.synopsis: In late 2021 I had taken a break from doing 3D to focus on programming, this piece was made during that time to get me back into the habit of animating. I also had lost my old earth asset and wanted to do a fun test with my newly created one.
items.description: Lol
items.tools: Blender, Quixel Megascans, After Effects, DaVinci Resolve

items.name: Full Animation
items.description: The full animation.

items.name: Full Animation
items.description: The full animation.

items.name: Base Animation
items.description: The full animation.

items.name: Maui Skit
items.synopsis: Using audio from the Disney film, Moana. I put my own spin on the character Maui.
items.description: Lol
items.tools: Blender, Quixel Megascans, After Effects, DaVinci Resolve

items.name: Full Animation
items.description: The finished animation. This was the first time that I had ever properly aniamted a dynamic character to audio.

items.name: Storyboard
items.description: The storyboard animation. I sadly wasn't able to put the same level of personality into the 3D character.

items.name: Blocking
items.description: Blocking. This gave me a good starting place as I wasn't sure how to animate Maui jumping around the scene.

items.name: Refining
items.description: I then realized that a good animation technique is to then animate the frame between two blocking poses and to keep doing that until the animation is smooth.

items.name: Final Viewport Animation
items.description: The final viewport animation. I wasn't too happy with Maui's speed due to the timing and size of the set, but it was a good animation excercise.

items.name: Lighting
items.description: A basic lighting test. I wanted to light the scene similar to how shots look in early 3D Disney animations.

items.name: Moving Day
items.synopsis: Moving Day was a short animation I made after making random sketches inside of the Blender. It explores the idea of what animals consider home.
items.description: Lol

items.name: Final Animation
items.description: The final animation. I was very pleased with how it turned out.

items.name: Sketch
items.description: The original concept. I wanted to contrast the dark environment of an attic with with a warm sunrise glow.

items.name: Paintover
items.description: Once I had finished modelling the attic, I did a paintover sketch in Krita to experiment with what details I wanted to add to the shot.

items.name: Rig
items.description: The mouse. I began with sculpting and then retopologized, textured, rigged, and groomed him.

items.name: Storyboard
items.description: A simple 3d storyboard. This let me figure out timing and framing.

items.name: Lighting
items.description: The final viewport animation. This was one of the first times that I had made and used a high quality rig, so I was still learning best animation practices.

items.name: Sci-Fi Plains
items.synopsis: Following the concept art by Thomas Dubois, I decided to experiment with large scale environments using Quixel's Megascans.
items.description: Lol

items.name: Final Animation

items.name: As the Paint Wears Away
items.synopsis: Racism has been an issue for the past decades, especially in America. This piece was a commentary on the American Dream and how behind all the shiny patriotic paint theres a much deeper systemic problem.
items.description: Lol

items.name: Final
items.description: The final piece. The paint represents the American Dream, and the fact it's being worn down is showing all of America's flaws. I chose to remove the eyes and ears from the sculpture to imply that people dont always see and hear the problem

items.name: WIP
items.description: The piece without the paint. I hadn't figured out what I wanted to tell with the piece yet.

items.name: P.66
items.synopsis: Inspired by the concept art of Fang Yi, I decided to try and re-create my favourite piece, P.66 Probe.
items.description: Lol

items.name: Final Render
items.description: The final render. I probably would have worked more on it if my computer handled the volumetrics better.

items.name: Breakdown
items.description: A breakdown of the original piece by Fang Yi. There were a tonn of buildings and I wanted to match the concept as closely as possible.

items.name: Buildings
items.description: A viewport render of the finished buildings.

items.name: Clouds
items.description: Figuring out how to do the clouds and mist was extremely challenging.

items.name: New Layout
items.description: I ended up changing the layout of the buildings because the previous setup wasnt working.

items.name: Personalized
items.description: Through giving myself more freedom to create, I was able to make the scene look better.

items.name: Viewport Animation
items.description: During this time I also had the idea of making a short horror animation.

items.name: Rendered Animation
items.description: I tried rendering it out but the sheer number of volumes broke my renders, so I gave up on the idea.

items.description: The app runs on Android and uses the MapBox API.

items.name: Fallout Shopping
items.synopsis: With humanity wiped from existance, a retail robot is finally free to enjoy what he loves most; Going shopping!
items.description: Lol

items.name: Fallout Shopping
items.description: The full animation took just under 2 full months to make. 1 month for concepting and planning, another for production.

items.name: Synopsis
items.description: A synposis page that I threw together. This helped me determine whether or not I wanted to make Fallout Shopping.

items.name: Storyboard
items.description: A video of the storyboard matched to the music. It helped me get my thoughts together and know how long each shot was going to be.

items.name: Concept 1
items.description: A concept page of how I wanted the scenes to look like.

items.name: Concept 2
items.description: Another page of concepts. I based most of the scenes off the Central Festival shopping mall in Chiang Mai.

items.name: Concept 3
items.description: Another page of concepts. I never completed outdoor environment because I thought I could wing it. It ended up being the worst shot in the entire animation.

items.name: Turntable
items.description: A turntable of the retail bot. I never gave him a name, he wasn't cool enough for that.

items.name: Retail Bot Sketchfab
items.description: An interactive model of the retail bot.

items.name: Lighting Test 1
items.description: An early lighting test of the opening shot. I struggled alot on trying to create a damaged apocalyptic floor.

items.name: Lighting Test 2
items.description: Another early lighting test. This shot gave me good experience on how to light a hallway when the main light source is from the back.

items.name: Lighting Test 3
items.description: This shot is what inspired me to make Fallout Shopping. I had imagined it weeks before I considered making it an animation.

items.name: Lamp Attack!
items.synopsis: We've all grown accustomed to the brutality we see in the Pixar intro. But what about those poor Pixar letters everywhere else?
items.description: Lol

items.name: Lamp Attack!
items.description: The Entire short film. I was amazed that a dumb idea I had while eating lunch ended up becoming a full short animaton.

items.name: Sketch
items.description: The first sketch. The entire animation was built off this one quick drawing.

items.name: Storyboard
items.description: This was the first time that I had made a storyboard for the entire short. As I was working in a team I wanted to show them what we were aiming for.

items.name: Rig
items.description: Rigging the letters was a fun experience for me. There were no tutorials online so my rigging ability was really put to the test.

items.name: Rig Demo
items.description: Rigging Luxo Jr. wasnt as difficult as there were numerous tutorials on how to do it.

items.name: Early Animation Test
items.description: Early animation test. I started with just the core actors as I wanted them to look perfect in the final shot.

items.name: Lighting Test
items.description: A lighting test. I wanted the spotlight to be the main source of light as it would give off a more horror-like mood.

items.name: Crowd Test
items.description: Finding a way to animate large crowds was a huge challenge. Here's one of my failed crowd tests.

items.name: Pixar Intro
items.description: While testing the letter and Luxo rigs, I made a mock Pixar intro.

items.name: Sparky
items.synopsis: In a quest to find a new power source for Glenton, a robot finds himself doing more harm than good. Or so it seems...
items.description: Lol

items.name: Sparky
items.description: The entire short film took about 16 months to make.

items.name: Early Concept
items.description: An early concept of Sparky. I thew this together as a test to see how his limbs would interect with surroundings.

items.name: Street
items.description: A screenshot of the road scene. Alot of duplication and moving was done for this.

items.name: Animation
items.description: A screenshot of Sparky during the animation phase. You can see we went for more tube based limbs so we could stretch Sparky as much as we needed to..

items.name: Turbines
items.description: An early shot of the turbines. The mountain was everntually removed from the shot but you can see the rest is relatively similar to the final.

items.name: Warehouse
items.description: An interior of the warehouse. Making sure that the render settings for this scene was extremely difficult due to the amount of noise that was generated.

items.name: Breeze Render Engine
items.synopsis: Breeze Render Engine is a C++ application that allows artists to create scenes in OpenGL and then render them out with Breeze's custom render engine.
items.description: After following the 'Ray Tracing in One Weekend' tutorial series, I became hooked on understanding how digital content creators used maths to display 3d models. This lead me to learn about OpenGL, and I quickly found some lessons on how it worked. After some time, I decided to make a rendering engine. Breeze Render Engine is my first ever C++ and Qt application. I spent around 8 months creating it with multiple rewrites. It was difficult, but I'm proud of how much I was able to learn.

items.name: Scene Example
items.description: A screenshot of a scene made in Breeze. You can download an try the application from my Github page.

items.name: Demo Video
items.description: A demo video of Breeze in action.

items.name: OBJ Importing
items.description: Breeze also allows custom OBJ importing.

items.name: Render
items.description: The render from the demo video.

items.name: Sicle Maps App
items.synopsis: Sicle Maps is a simplified alternative to Google Maps. Users can track their location and follow routes to their desired destination.
items.description: After seeing some modern app designs on Dribbble, I was inspired to write my own mobile application. Since I'm an avid cyclist, I wanted to make an application that I could use. The solution was a simplified google maps called 'Sicle'. While creating Sicle, I was able to understand how to use Android Studio, and how to build and run Kotlin code.

items.name: App Screenshot
items.description: A screenshot of the app in use.

items.name: App Demo Video
items.description: The app runs on Android and uses the MapBox API.

items.name: School Designs
items.synopsis: I was given the opportunity at Chiang Mai International School to add my own personal touch to some walls! My designs can now be seen in the high school art classroom and the school gym.
items.description: After completing my submission for AP 2D Art & Design, my art teacher suggested that I decorate the art room pillars. During that time, I was also approached by the school to make designs for the school gym. I jumped at the chance to leave a legacy at Chiang Mai International School, and by the start of the next school year, both projects were completed.

items.name: Pillars
items.description: A photo of both completed pillars. We named the closest one 'Boogle' and the other 'Night Sky'

items.name: A photo of me painting 'Boogle'. Although I worked with a couple of other students on the pillars, 'Boogle' was primarily my piece.
items.description: A photo of me working on the first pillar.

items.name: Polaroid
items.description: A polaroid of me painting 'Night Sky' with my art teacher and a couple other students. We only had a week before school ended for the summer so it was all hands on deck.

items.name: Painting Video
items.description: A video I took while painting. At the time I was staying an extra 2 hours at school each day to get the project done.

items.name: Measuring Walls
items.description: A photo taken of me when I was estimating how large the designs should be on the wall.

items.name: Full Frame
items.description: A full frame shot of the gym that I composited together inside of Nuke. I used this image to pitch the idea to the school board.

items.name: Website
items.synopsis: I custom built this website! With HTML, CSS, Javascript and a lot of love, everything you see here was programmed by me.
items.description: I had always wanted to make my own website. I learnt the basics of web design in 2019, but since then I hadn't used them for anything useful. One day I sat down and decided to put that knowledge to good use, and after a year of designing, building, redesigning and rebuilding, I finally built a website that I'm proud of.

items.name: Home Page
items.description: The wonderful home page.
